PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Newton s 'Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica' Geneva Edition & the Relationship between Physics and Mathematics
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Newton Geneva Project is a research whose final scope is to rework main conceptual scientific frameworks of the whole Newtonian Geneva edition (GE), taking into account within historical epistemology of science the complex share knowledge in context, as well. Conspicuous pieces of information as to history of physics, history of mathematics and epistemology can be drawn from it. We are at the core of the birth of modern science, so some lines on Newtonian historiography is necessary. It is know that Wallis and Wallis (1977) worked on that, and their account is crucial text up to 1975. In this research, my general aim is to put in evidence all the conceptual aspects of this edition and its role inside the Scientific Revolution, as well as highlighting the complex relations between the emerging new science and its surrounding civilization. This research has an introductory purpose for a research we are carrying out. The final purposes of the research are: 1) a clear delineation of the relations between mathematics and physics inside the Principia. In other terms: how the particular way in which Newton used geometry and infinitesimal procedures influenced his physics; 2) the comprehension why and how Newton s mathematical methods were progressively, but rapidly, replaced by more analytical methods. This second part has profound connections with the development of science and mathematics in the society. After the publication of Newton s Principia many authors (i.e, Varignon, Gregory, Jakob, Johann and Daniel, Euler, etc.) tried to better and deepen analytically explain both transcriptions and Newton s results. On the other hand, because its mixed geometrical physical mathematical astronomical contents, a definitive revision was hard and still nowadays (i.,e Principia, Vols. II-III) far from being complete. Subsequently, Geneva edition has a set of remarks more extended than Newton s manuscript itself: e.g., explanations of the results and above all of Newton s methods. An editorial project in ﬁve volumes (Oxford University Press) concerning the GE is in start-up phase. We aim at providing a critical translation into English of the four Latin volumes (1822), and an added introductory volume
